claims_to_validate.claim_text: Current system does not support automatic salary calculation based on actual working days, requiring manual interventions and separate tracking.

The daily wage calculator in payroll settings intentionally overrides the leave policy formula for unpaid leave. The leave policy formula appears greyed out, indicating it is not the active calculation method. This creates user confusion about which formula is actually being applied.

System failed to recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions when new salary configurations were created after leave request submission. Deductions were calculated based on previous salary configuration instead of current one, resulting in incorrect payroll deduction amount.

The system incorrectly calculates service days by using 365 days instead of 366 days for 2024, resulting in an inaccurate gratuity amount. When calculating End of Service (EOS) gratuity, the system fails to recognize 2024 as a leap year, causing a calculation discrepancy of approximately AED 17.26.

Daily wage calculation for pro-rated amounts produces consistently lower amounts by 0.1 or 0.2 decimals. The formula (basic + allowances / 30) is configured correctly, but results in slightly incorrect End of Service (EOS) calculations across all employees.

System gratuity calculation (AED 231,821) slightly differs from manual calculation (AED 252,485). Detailed breakdown shows system calculation follows specific service duration and daily wage formula rules.

The system's gratuity calculation may not consistently handle leap year days (specifically February 29th), causing minor discrepancies in total service days calculation. The system calculated 912 days, while the manual calculation included 913 days by explicitly counting the leap day.
System calculates 623 days instead of 622 days when computing gratuity, adding one extra day to the total job tenure calculation.

System calculates leave salary using a predefined daily rate configuration that may not align with user expectations about calendar days. The specific case showed a calculation dividing daily wage by 30 days instead of 31 days, resulting in a slight salary amount difference (2940 SAR vs expected 2988 SAR).

The daily wage calculator's 'working days' setting causes monthly fluctuations in leave salary accrual calculations. The daily wage rate changes based on the number of working days in each month, leading to inconsistent cumulative totals.

The system uses different divisors for leave salary (30 days) and salary proration (30.42 days), causing calculation discrepancies. Leave salary and salary proration are configured independently, leading to potential mismatches in daily wage calculations.

User initially misunderstood how working days are calculated based on work week configuration. The system was actually calculating correctly, but the user did not initially understand that their specific work week (NVK Operations) had all 7 days configured as working days.

The system fails to correctly prorate salaries when an employee's departure date is in the future relative to payroll processing date. When an employee is offboarded (e.g., on Nov 28th) and payroll is processed earlier (e.g., on Nov 27th), the system displays the full monthly salary instead of a prorated amount.

When an unpaid leave request is approved and transaction submitted, then the daily wage calculation is changed and the transaction deleted to recalculate, the system creates duplicate deductions—one with the old calculation and one with the new. Moving the leave request back to pending/accepted does not resolve the issue. Even after deleting the unpaid leave request entirely, the unpaid leave deduction persists in payroll deductions.

The system experiences data synchronization problems between Time Off and Payroll modules when public holidays are added after leave requests. This causes mismatches in daily wage calculations, resulting in incorrect salary deductions that cannot be retroactively corrected.

The system uses a custom daily wage divisor (30.42 days) instead of calendar days, which can produce deduction amounts that differ from user expectations, potentially causing confusion about calculation methods.
The system displays incorrect daily rate remarks for February, showing 31 days instead of 29 days (leap year), despite the underlying calculation being mathematically correct.

The system applies a global daily rate configuration that supersedes individual leave policy calculations for unpaid leave deductions. This results in deductions being calculated using a system-wide setting instead of policy-specific methods.

The system shows the daily rate from the payroll month (May) instead of the leave occurrence month (April), causing user confusion. The actual deduction amount is calculated correctly, but the displayed daily rate does not reflect the month when leave occurred.
